Markdown Links from Firefox Tabs

Sep 7, 2014
1 minute read

I just updated my up-to-date text expansion guide with some new goodies. Of particular note are two new snippets related to grabbing the current tab in Firefox and making a Markdown link out of it.

This turned out to be harder than I anticipated: although Chrome and Safari have AppleScript support for grabbing the document title and URL of their current tabs, Firefox can only grab the title.1

TL;DR

Create an AppleScript that fully automates the retrieval of the current Firefox window/tab’s title and URL, then creates a Markdown link from it.

The Process

I hunted around a bit and ran across a method in the Alfred forums that grabs the URL in a rather hacky way: use AppleScript to switch to Firefox and simulate the Command + L/Command + C key sequence (which, as you might surmise, moves the focus to the Omnibar and copies its contents).

Although the Alfred forum members were not overly satisfied with this solution2, it had enough promise for my particular uses. The only thing missing was the automatic return to the “caller” application (that is, the application into which the TextExpander/aText snippet was entered). Fortunately, this wasn’t hard to add:

Hopefully, the Mozilla folks will someday add proper support for this transaction. Until then, enjoy!

  1. Unfortunately, given the staleness of the “Add Applescript Support to Firefox” ticket on Bugzilla (the last update was in February of 2013), I’m not overly hopeful that this will get addressed anytime soon. ↩
  2. Let’s be fair: I’m not, either. However, at the end of the day, when you need something to work, you’re willing to put aside notions of “hacky-ness” and move forward. ↩
